ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CLOSED CIRCUIT VIDEO CAMERAS IN SCHOOLS
(Installation)


    1. Dr Lau Teik Soon asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education his views concerning the installation of closed circuit video cameras in schools.

     The Minister of State of Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): The Ministry of Education does not install closed circuit television cameras in

Column: 1484

schools. The Member is probably referring to Manjusri Secondary School, The school, an aided-school, recently installed closed circuit TV cameras to try to improve the security of their car parks, technical workshops, the air-rifle range and the school field. The system was paid for by funds raised by the School's Management Committee.

    Vandalism of school property, especially outside school hours, is a problem in a number of schools. But the Ministry has had to phase out night watchmen because it has become increasingly difficult to recruit such people. Improvements in fencing and physical security measures will help to reduce the incidence of vandalism. But I doubt if closed circuit TV is an effective answer to this problem.

POLYTECHNIC COURSES IN PREFERENCE TO 'A' LEVEL COURSES
(Reasons)


    2. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (a) how many students, who obtained an aggregate of 10 points and less in five subjects in the 1983 'O' level examinations, opted to join the polytechnics instead of advancing to the 'A' levels, and what were their reasons; (b) what has been the outcome of efforts to persuade them to go for the 'A' levels; and (c) whether his Ministry will closely monitor this phenomenon of students opting to take a diploma course instead of going to the 'A' levels and then to the University.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, out of 3,202 students with 10 points or less in the 1983 'O' level examinations, 403 opted to join the polytechnics instead of the junior colleges. They comprise basically of two groups. One group who are from the Chinese stream would have to pass ELl at 'O' level at junior college to qualify for admission to NUS. They expressed lack of confidence to do so as the main reason for opting for the polytechnics.

    The second group are students who do not have confidence in passing the General Paper. They have the miscomprehension that a Pass in GP is essential for admission to NUS. Except for the Law Faculty, NUS does not require a Pass in GP, although GP does count for points.

    Most of the 403 students came to a counselling session on 7th April, 1984, organised by my Ministry, Ninety-two of them opted for the 'A' level course after. the counselling.

    My Ministry considers it a loss that good students should opt to take a diploma instead of going to 'A' level and then to the university. Furthermore, such students are taking up places at the polytechnics which could better go to those who are unlikely to make it through 'A' level and the university. For example, altogether, 2,026 students with 17 points or below who are qualified to join the junior colleges opted for the polytechnics this year. On the other

Column: 1486

hand, 821 students who wanted to join the polytechnics could not do so because of lack of vacancies and instead had to join the Pre-U centres. It would be preferable if more of the students with 17 points or below joined the junior colleges, thus releasing places for those who instead had to go to Pre-U centres.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, since only 92 of the 403 students who went to the Ministry for counselling, went for the 'A' level, would the Ministry consider giving those students who have got a better chance to take the 'A' level and then go to the university, more opportunities and encouraging them at the same time? In this respect, what steps are being taken to encourage them, instead of the other way round where more of the students who are not able to secure a place in the polytechnics go to the 'A' level instead?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Mr Speaker, Sir, my Ministry is looking into various ways and alternatives in which this problem of the reversal of enrolment of bright students in the polytechnics can be corrected for the future.

ADMISSION TO SCHOOLS
(Priority Registration for Graduate Mothers)


    3. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (a) how many graduate mothers have registered their third child for Primary One in 1985 under the priority Phase 1A scheme and what were the schools of their choice; (b) whether such priority scheme has affected the chances of those in the other priority schemes of registration to be carried out later; and (c) how long will this scheme last.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, a total of 157 graduate mothers applied under Phase 1A for Primary 1 and Pre-Primary places under the new registration scheme.

    They applied for places in a total of 36 schools. The schools ranged from the better known ones such as ACS, Nanyang Primary School and Catholic High School, to lesser known ones such as Sembawang

Column: 1487

Hills Estate, Kong Hwa and Canberra Primary School.

    The number of pupils registered under Phase IA in any of the 36 schools do not amount to even half a class. They will not affect the chances of those coming in later phases of the scheme.

    The Member has asked how long the new scheme will last. As I have explained previously in this House and elsewhere, we are faced with a dual problem, namely, that many of our graduate women are not marrying and when they do, they are having very small families. The purpose of the registration scheme is to draw attention to this problem in the hope that over a period of time the very lopsided procreation pattern that we now have will rectify itself. It is too early for me to say how long this will take.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, two supplementary questions. First, out of the 157 graduate mothers who applied under this priority scheme Phase 1A, could the Minister of State enlighten this House as to the number who would qualify to have their third child under this Phase 1A scheme? Secondly, could he also enlighten this House on the number of those graduate mothers who have only two children and who have registered under Phase 1 B with the Ministry, and how many of them qualify under this scheme?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Mr Speaker, Sir, in answer to his first question, out of the 157 who applied, 147 were given places. As to the second question regarding Phase 1B, which is just over, there are basically two groups of pupils involved. There are those who have brothers or sisters in the school that they are applying for and they are getting priority as in previous years under Phase 1. This comprised the vast majority of applicants for schools under Phase 1. They totalled 9,053 and they were registered in 146 primary schools.

    The second category under Phase 1 B are graduate mothers with two children. A total of 403 applied for and were offered places in a total of 55 schools.

Column: 1488



     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, would the Minister of State assure the House that such a scheme will not in any way affect the priorities of others?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Mr Speaker, Sir, from the figures I have just quoted, the vast majority of people are receiving places under the priority as in previous years, and the number who come from the category of graduate mothers is not large in comparison.

PIG FARMING
(Phasing out)


    4. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education, in view of the bleak future of pig farming in Singapore, (a) if he will allow the phasing out of the smaller pig farms which was carried out last year to be continued so as to enable these farmers to use the resettlement benefits to look for alternative means of livelihood, allowing those who wish to remain to do so; and (b) whether he will state his views on the future of those medium-sized pig farmers who were encouraged by the Primary Production Department to extend their farms to a commercial basis and as a result spent large sums of money on such extensions and of those large commercial pig farms which have incurred expenditure of millions of dollars on improvements and developments which are in various stages of completion.

     The First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I presume that the Member for Punggol is referring to the 71 pig farms on Temporary Occupation Licences in his constituency for which resettlement proceedings had been suspended pending the Government's review of pig farming policy in Singapore. Resettlement proceedings for these farms had since resumed on a voluntary basis. 59 of them had opted for voluntary clearance. They will receive full resettlement benefits averaging at about $190,000 per farm. The option for voluntary clearance will be given so long as farms served with clearance notices are sited on land not required for development purposes, ie the option for the 71 TOL farmers.

Column: 1489



    Such farmers who choose not to exercise the option can remain on their farms. They can continue with pig farming so long as they can maintain pollution control standards when these are set by the Ministry of the Environment. Otherwise, they will have to convert to non-pollutive farming, such as vegetable farming or fish farming. The Government will assist them in their conversion from pig farming. The cessation of pig farming is not synonymous with clearance from the land. Farmers whose farms are not sited on land required for development purposes will not be served with clearance notices. They can remain on their farms and continue pig rearing for the time being. When the Ministry of the Environment sets pollution control standards, they will be required to comply, failing which they will have to convert to non-pollutive farming. Every assistance will be given by the Primary Production Department for them to do so,

    As regards the second part of his Question, 85 medium-sized TOL farms in Punggol were advised by the Primary Production Department during 1983 to amalgamate into larger commercial units so as to qualify for the capital grant to build pig waste treatment plants. 54 of them have since been merged into 36 commercial farms. While topographical surveys have been carried out on them, little development work has been undertaken. With the rescission of the Capital Grant Scheme for the construction of pig waste treatment plants on 22nd June this year, the rationale for these farms to convert into commercial farms no longer exists. So long as they are not sited on land required for development purposes, the farmers will be allowed to remain on them. Should they wish to continue with pig farming, they will, at some future date, be required to satisfy Environment's pollution control standards. Otherwise, they will also have to convert to non-pollutive farming. This principle also holds for the large commercial farms.

    The Member for Punggol may like to note that the Government will compensate commercial pig farms for the expenditure incurred in relation to the design and construction of pig waste treatment plants. The total amount of compensation will not

Column: 1490

be known exactly until all claims have been assessed. It is likely to be in the region of $25 million.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, while those farmers affected would be grateful to the Hon. First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education for his generous reply, I would like to ask him whether other TOL holders of medium-sized pig farms, who are now not affected by this scheme but who may be affected at some future date by land acquisition for development purposes, would also enjoy similar resettlement benefits?

     Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, whenever the Government acquires land for development purposes, the usual generous rates of compensation will be paid.

     Mr Tang See Chim (Chua Chu Kang): Mr Speaker, Sir, in respect of farmers whose lands have not been served with notices of clearance, would the Government give them an option to elect for earlier resettlement?

     Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, I see no reason why we should give them compensation or resettlement terms when we do not acquire their land?

     Mr Tang See Chim: Sir, does the Minister not think that the land would be better used if the Government allowed the farmers to opt for earlier resettlement?

     Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, if the land could be more profitably used, say, for commercial or residential purposes and if the Minister for National Development requires such land, then, of course, the land will be acquired and the generous terms will apply. But just because they may not be able to rear pigs at some future date, at a time when we do not need to acquire their land, there is no reason why we should pay out such handsome sums of money.

     Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Minister not recall that at the last Budget debate, he said that the Government was subsidizing pig farmers as a result of which he thought that the future of pig farming was very bleak because the land on which pig farms were being used had not been put to its optimum use.

Column: 1491



     Dr Goh Keng Swee: I did say that, but I did not say that they would be acquired in the next year or two. Farmers will have to be patient. Singapore will develop. The Member for Chua Chu Kang need not worry that between now and the next general elections this will be a major problem in his constituency.

     Mr Tang See Chim: Sir, I thought that the whole premise of the Minister's statement that the future of pig farming was bleak was that the land had not been put to its optimum use. Does the Minister now agree that pig farming is, in fact, putting the land to its optimum use?

     Dr Goh Keng Swee: Yes, of course. But why does he want compensation for his farmers now when we do not require the land?

Column: 1491

OFFICIAL RECEIVER
(Appointments in private civil actions)


    5. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Law to state the number of instances in which over the last ten years the Official Receiver has accepted appointment as receiver for the purpose of executing judgments of the courts in private civil actions where no element of public interest or public monies was involved.

     The Minister for Labour and Second Minister for Law and Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar)(for the Minister for Law): Mr Speaker, Sir, the only instance in the past 10 years where the Official Receiver was so appointed as Receiver was the case of the Workers' Party. It was not a question of the Official Receiver accepting appointment. He was ordered to be appointed Receiver by an Order of Court dated 3rd June, 1982, upon the application of Mr Tay Boon Too, a creditor of the Workers' Party, who had not been paid his legal costs for many years. In the past 10 years or more, no other political party has kept its bank accounts with so small a sum as $18.47 in order to avoid paying costs it owed, thus making it necessary for this legal procedure to be invoked.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, first of all, is it the Hon. Minister's statement that the Official Receiver was ordered by the Court to take

Column: 1492

up appointment as Receiver in this suit, or is he saying that the Official Receiver consented in the first place to accept appointment? May we know which one is it that he is stating?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have here a copy of the Court Order. It is clear that the Court ordered it, and I quote:

    'it is ordered that the Official Receiver, Mr Lim Ewe Huat, be and is hereby appointed Receiver in this action subject to the usual terms to be settled by the Assistant Registrar of the High Court...'.

and so on.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Sir, is the Minister saying that before the Order was made, the Official Receiver was not asked if he would accept appointment? And is the Minister going on to say that he did not accept such appointment but, nevertheless, was appointed by the Court?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson is raising questions of detail here which properly ought to have been raised in the Court hearing at the appropriate time. He should let us know whether he had raised legal objections when these Court hearings came out. Did he object to the appointment of the Official Receiver as Receiver? If not, why is he now trying to convert this Chamber into an Appellate Court for having failed to raise these questions in the Court?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Sir, would the Minister please answer the questions that are put to him? Would he not agree that they are simple enough for him to understand? If they are not simple enough, then perhaps we can try and write them out for him in a more simple language.

    Perhaps, Mr Speaker, Sir, before I asked my first supplementary question, I should have told you that I have no pecuniary personal interest in this matter but, of course, it concerns the appointment in my Party suit. Would the Minister say whether he agrees that the application was the suit of a private individual, and he was not even an MP at that time, against a private society? Would the Minister say whether it is one of the functions of the Official Receiver that he should accept appointment to enable private individuals to recover their judgments in Court?

Column: 1493



     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member is raising the same point that he has mentioned in framing the Question. In other words, he is implying that this whole case was one where no element of public interest or monies was involved. Mr Speaker, Sir, on the contrary, I take the view that there is certainly an element of public interest when a political party which claims to be responsible, which wants to contest elections, which wants to form the Government and whose leader desperately wants to be the Prime Minister, nevertheless deliberately refrains from meeting its obligations arising from litigation which it itself has instituted.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Minister not realize that he is completely missing the point of the questions put to him? Does the Minister not realize that it was open to Mr Tay Boon Too, the defendant in that suit, to have got another receiver to accept appointment and the Court could have appointed this other individual? There are hundreds of accountants or other people in Singapore who would be prepared to accept appointment as receiver. The question is: why was it found necessary for the Official Receiver, a man who is paid from public funds, a civil servant, to accept appointment in a private suit?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, although I believe that these are points which he ought to have raised but failed to raise in the Court hearing, let me answer his point. It might have been possible for some other Receiver to have been appointed. I do not know why the litigant here had applied for the Official Receiver. My Ministry was not involved in this. But let me say that the Member for Anson, far from complaining, in fact, should express his gratitude because I am informed that the costs which he had to pay for the Official Receiver's functions were far cheaper than would have been the case if any other accountant or other official in the private sector had been appointed.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, another supplementary question for the Hon. Minister. May 1, first of all, repeat my earlier questions and beg him to answer them. If he is unable to answer them,

Column: 1494

perhaps he might make a statement that he is unable to answer them. The question now is this. Does he not think that it is a corrupt use of public funds that the Official Receiver should have accepted appointment in a suit which did not concern the Government and where there was no public interest involved?
